page.title: Certificates of Completion
page.contents:
You can earn a certificate of completion for this unit by completing the five unit activities. 

To earn a certificate of completion for this unit, you will need to do the following:

  • Identify ways that you use digital skills in your own life.
  • Complete two Northstar Digital Literacy Assessment modules.
  • Create two online forms to supplement chapters from Staying Healthy or from two lessons that you use in your teaching.
  • Create one classroom e-mail activity to add to Staying Healthy Chapter 1 or an e-mail activity to add to a unit or lesson that you use in your teaching.

page.title: Introduction for Administrators
page.contents:
Welcome to Unit 1 of Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction: Professional Development Module

The following elements are included in this unit:

  • The need for digital literacy for adult English language learners’ lives

  • The important roles for administrators

  • The essential conditions to support digital literacy development throughout programs

  • Technology plans

  • Technology environments

The unit will take about 1 hour to complete, depending on how deeply you delve into the variety of resources provided.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0010.mp3

Audio transcript


This section of “Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our Lives,” is addressed specifically to administrators. It includes information about adult English language learners’ (ELLs’) needs for digital skills, the important role that administrators play in integrating digital literacy into programs and classes, and the essential conditions necessary to support digital literacy development throughout programs. Technology plans are discussed, along with different technology environments, including bring-your-own-device (BYOD) environments. The section ends with questions to guide your thinking about where your program is now and what you would like to see for the future.

page.title: Consequences of Low Foundational Skills, Including Digital Literacy Skills
page.contents:
Adults, including English-language-learning adults, with weak basic skills exhibit the following characteristics:

[They] are less likely to vote or volunteer in their communities and are more likely to suffer poor health. In fact, adults with low skills are four times more likely to report “fair” or “poor” health than those with strong skills. This relationship [in the United States] is twice as strong as the international average (U.S. Department of Education, 2013, p. 5).

You can read the full report here:

http://www.timetoreskill.org/consultation-paper.pdf

If you like to read deeply about a subject, look at all the “To Go Deeper” items, which are articles in academic journals and books that describe research studies or developing theories. Most of the To Go Deeper items can be found online at your local public or academic library.

To Go Deeper


For details on one example of integrating digital health literacy into a health literacy/ESL curriculum in an adult education setting, see Mein, Fuentes, and Soto (2012). You can copy and paste the reference into any format.

Reference: Mein, E., Fuentes, B., & Soto, F. (2012). Incorporating digital health literacy into adult ESL education on the US-Mexico border. Rhetoric Professional Communication and Globalization, 3(1), 162–174.

page.title: Consequences
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0030.mp3

Audio transcript


Adult ELLs have the challenge of developing basic English skills, in addition to developing strong skills in reading, mathematics, problem solving, and using technology, which makes it more likely that the doors of 21st-century workplaces will be closed to them.

“Adults who have trouble reading, doing math, solving problems, and using technology will find the doors of the 21st century workforce closed to them”.(U.S. Department of Education, 2013, p. 2)

Research with employers indicates that the need for digital skills in the workforce will only increase.

Consequences of Low Foundational Skills in the Area of Employment

Among the applied skills that are expected to increase in importance in the next 5 years, information technology application is ranked by employers as the second-highest applied skill. Information technology application includes digital skills such as the following:

  • The ability to select and use appropriate technology to accomplish a given task

  • The ability to apply computing skills to problem solving

You can read the full report (Are They Really Ready for Work) here:

http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED519465.pdf

Listen to audio: 

ELL_Mod2_0040.mp3

Audio transcript


The ability to select and use appropriate technology to accomplish a given task and apply computing skills to solve problems—which together comprise an information technology application—is ranked by employers as the second-highest applied skill and is expected to increase in importance in the next 5 years.

page.title: What does it mean?
page.contents:
What does this mean? All students need to learn skills in English listening, speaking, reading, and writing in a variety of real-world contexts, including digital contexts.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0050.mp3

Audio transcript


What does this mean for students? All adult students, including ELLs, will need to learn skills in English listening, speaking, reading, and writing in a variety of real-world contexts, including digital contexts. These skills are required for adult ELLs to earn high school diplomas or a general equivalency diplomas (GEDs), transition to postsecondary education or training, and obtain employment or improved employment opportunities, in addition to achieving the many other goals that adult ELLs have.

page.title: For Administrators: Part 2
page.contents:
Program, district, and state administrators play an important role in enabling the integration of digital literacy into adult English-language-acquisition classes and programs.

A review of research on technology use in schools suggests the following:

Technology, by itself, is not likely to bring about reforms in schools, but it can be a powerful tool for educators if it is part of a comprehensive and systemic effort to change education. According to Moeller and Reitzes (2011), technology is most likely to be widely adopted by teachers and schools if it has the following characteristics:

(1) It supports already existing practices and helps to solve problems or address challenges.

(2) It is part of a systemic, organization-wide initiative.

(3) Teachers have access to ample professional development and ongoing support.

(Moeller & Reitzes, 2011)

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0060.mp3

Audio transcript


A very clear picture emerges from research on the integration of technology into education. Much of the research comes from K–12 settings, but the findings are readily generalized to adult-English-language-acquisition settings. Administrators play a very important role by supporting teachers as they integrate digital literacy into their classes. Administrators play a key role in all three factors that relate to successful technology adoption:

*Helping craft a technology plan that supports existing practices and the use of technology to solve problems or address challenges
*Ensuring that technology is part of a systemic, organization-wide initiative
*Providing teachers with ample professional development time and ongoing support

English language acquisition (ELA) teachers, in particular, need support. Often working part time and at multiple sites, ELA teachers have restricted access to school-based technologies, little access to support for using these technologies, and limited access to professional development related to these technologies. Although these teachers encounter significant barriers to necessary supports, ELA teachers also work with students who have very high needs to develop language and technology skills. Given both challenges, the needs of ELLs and those who teach them must be central to a program’s technology plan.

page.title: Conditions Necessary to Effectively Leverage Technology for Learning
page.contents:
The International Society for Technology in Education  

Essential conditions

  • Shared vision

  • Planning for implementation

  • Ongoing professional learning

  • Technical support

  • Others

International Society for Technology in Education. (2009). Essential conditions: Necessary conditions to effectively leverage technology for learning. Arlington, VA: Author.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0070.mp3

Audio transcript


The International Society for Technology in Education has created a list of the 14 essential conditions for effectively leveraging technology for learning. There is wide agreement between these essential conditions and educational research.

In particular, having a shared vision, a systematic plan for implementation, ongoing professional learning, and technical support appear in many different reports. In this unit, we will discuss creating a technology plan, which includes crafting a shared vision, as well as supports for ongoing professional learning and technical support. We will examine one technology environment in particular—BYOD—and illustrate its pros and cons.

page.title: A Plan for Technology
page.contents:
Having a shared, coherent, and consistent vision for the role of technology is key to the success of technology integration (Means, 2010; Moeller & Reitzes, 2011).

An effective technology plan has the following characteristics:

  • Is based on shared vision

  • Ensures that technology strengthens existing curricula and programs

  • Supports meaningful, engaged learning for all students

  • Specifies how technology resources are paid for and supported (adapted from November et al., 1998)

The Who’s Online Where Index uses information on the following:

  • The adult education eligible population

  • Internet usage and access

It produces an index score that helps determine where to implement or expand online or hybrid instructional programming.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0080.mp3

Audio transcript


To reap the benefits of technology, schools must develop a plan for integrating technology into their curricula. An effective technology plan is based on the shared vision of educators, administrators, community members, and business leaders who have technological expertise. Such a plan ensures that technology strengthens the existing curricula and supports meaningful, engaged learning for all students. An effective technology plan also specifies how the technology will be paid for and how its use will be supported. A shared vision results from joint planning among administrators, teachers, and other stakeholders.

Another aspect of technology is that the Internet can help reach more learners who need adult education programs, including adult ELA programs. State directors and program administrators need data to help determine where to offer face-to-face, hybrid, or fully online adult education programs to reach more learners who need the programs. The Who’s Online Where Index takes into consideration several factors related to population demographics and broadband Internet access predictors. This providies administrators with county-level information about where the eligible adult population lives and how likely it is that the population can conveniently access the Internet. The resulting index score corresponds with the intervention recommendations that help state directors and others determine where to implement or expand online or hybrid instructional programming.

page.title: Technology Environments
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0100.mp3

Audio transcript


Part of developing a technology plan is describing where your program is now with respect to technology adoption and use. A variety of technology environments in programs serve adult ELLs, including but not limited to computer labs, computers in classrooms (e.g., a row of computers at the back of some classrooms), mobile classroom sets of laptops or tablets, and reliance on student tools. Using student tools is currently called BYOD (bring your own device), but its name may change by the time you complete this module.

  Other technology environments are not mentioned here, and each has pros and cons. At the time that this unit was created, national discussions were ongoing in educational technology circles regarding the value of BYOD environments.

  Administrators can help students get onto the Internet and can bring more Internet into classrooms through Everyone On, a national Internet access campaign. Through Everyone On, individuals can find Internet service for as little as $10 a month, low-cost computers, and free digital literacy courses. Read more about the program at the link on your screen.

page.title: Bring Your Own Devices: Are They Right for Your Program?
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0110.mp3

Audio transcript


Real advantages exist in using digital devices that students own and bring with them. Students know how to use the devices and will be using the same devices when they are not in class. This promotes consistency for learners, especially those who struggle with digital skills or language, such as ELLs. BYOD is increasingly used in corporate, as well as education, environments and is associated with increased productivity and decreased costs.

In some ways, however, a program that uses student-provided devices is not different from a program that has program-provided devices. For example, BYOD programs will still need to have extra devices for students who do not own or bring their own devices. Technical support is just as important in BYOD contexts as it is in lab or classroom contexts and may be more difficult because of the range of devices to support. One big disadvantage, shared by Steve Quann of World Education (personal communication), is that in BYOD settings, teachers are limited to software programs and apps that operate equally well on all the platforms used by students in the class. Cross-platform software and apps were not readily available at the time this module was created. They may become more readily available with time, but the lack of compatibility also may be too great a problem. Nevertheless, it is important for programs to consider the issues involved in selecting a technology environment.

Providing time and support for teachers to plan—ideally, collaboratively—is just as important in BYOD contexts as it is in every technology environment. Support for teachers is absolutely essential for successful technology integration and thus the potential to integrate digital tasks across the curriculum.

AdvantagesNo DifferenceDisadvantages
  • Students know how to use the devices they bring.
  • Students will be using the same devices when they are not in class.
  • Increasing BYOD use exists in corporate, as well as education environments.
  • Personal devices are associated with increased productivity and decreased costs.
  • Programs still need to have devices for students to use who do not own or bring their own devices.
  • Technical support continues to be very important.
  • Providing time and support for teachers to plan collaboratively and individually continues to be essential.
  • Programs and teachers need to select software and apps that are available on all the platforms used by students.
  • Cross-platform software and apps are not readily available.

For a summary of BYOD, see Johnson, Adams Becker, Estrada, and Freeman (2014).

page.title: Pedagogical Implications
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0130.mp3

Audio transcript


When teachers have access to technology and the support to use it with their students, whether BYOD or a classroom set of devices, the way that the class operates can change. Because technology and its uses change rapidly, everyone is a learner. All members of the classroom have different experiences and expertise with technologies, so that knowledge is distributed. There is far less “sage on the stage,” partially because the “stage” in the room is gone, as represented by the picture. In the realm of technology, the teacher is more likely to be a facilitator than an expert. When the students can be the experts and the teacher can be the facilitator, student-centered approaches are supported. In these approaches, students learn language through digital tasks and learn digital skills through language learning. When digital tasks are integrated across the curriculum, students learn basic digital skills by engaging in meaningful, relevant digital tasks.

Because of the rapid and constant evolution of technology, everyone is a learner.

Students and teachers all have different experiences and skills with technology.

The teacher is more likely to be a facilitator, not an expert.

Student-centered learning approaches, such as project-based and problem-based learning approaches, are supported.

In these approaches, students learn language through digital tasks and digital skills through language learning (Quann & Satin, 2000).

When digital tasks are integrated across the curriculum, students learn basic digital skills by engaging in meaningful, relevant digital tasks.

page.title: Introduction
page.contents: This unit is an overview for instructors and administrators about framing digital literacy as a critical component for language skill development. By participating in this unit, teachers can learn how to integrate digital literacy instruction and learning activities into all aspects of adult English language learner (ELL) instruction.

page.title: Introduction for Teachers
page.contents:
Welcome to Unit 1 of Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction: Professional Development Module.

The following elements are included in this unit:

  • An exploration of your own digital literacy skills
  • A basic definition of digital literacy
  • Reasons why adult English-language-learning students need digital literacy skills
  • Strategies to integrate digital tasks into an existing curriculum
  • Hands-on activities
  • Guidelines for making digital tasks for any lesson, unit, or curriculum

This unit will take between 2 and 3 hours to complete, depending on how deeply you delve into the resources provided.

page.title: For Administrators: Part 1
page.contents:
Focus on Students

For participation in modern workplaces and contemporary life, individuals need foundational skills that include the following:

A combination of literacy, numeracy, and English language (i.e., listening, reading, writing, speaking in English, digital literacy, and the use of mathematical ideas); and employability skills.

(U.S. Department of Education, 2013, p. 3)

Digital literacy goes hand in hand with increased rigor of instruction, so that students work with complex texts and hone their critical thinking skills.

More information is in Meeting the Language Needs of Today’s Adult English Language Learner: Professional Development Module

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0020.mp3

Audio transcript


Many reasons explain why adult ELLs need digital literacy skills, along with traditionally taught English language skills. For participation in modern workplaces and contemporary life, individuals need foundational skills that include a combination of literacy, numeracy, and the use of mathematical ideas. For adult ELLs, the foundational skills present a big mountain to climb; they need to develop English skills in listening, reading, writing, and speaking, as well as learn to operate in digital environments in their new language. Digital literacy goes hand in hand with increased rigor of instruction, so that students work with complex texts and hone their critical thinking skills. The module titled “Meeting the Language Needs of Today’s Adult English Language Learner” contains more information on this concept. In this section, we will briefly address the reasons that digital literacy is so important to all adult learners and ELLs in particular.
